speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And that the French were almost ten to one,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Before we met or that a stroke was given,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Like to a trusty squire did run away:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In which assault we lost twelve hundred men;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Myself and divers gentlemen beside

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Were there surprised and taken prisoners.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Then judge, great lords, if I have done amiss;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Or whether that such cowards ought to wear

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: This ornament of knighthood, yea or no.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To say the truth, this fact was infamous

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And ill beseeming any common man,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Much more a knight, a captain and a leader.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: When first this order was ordaind, my lords,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Knights of the garter were of noble birth,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Valiant and virtuous, full of haughty courage,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Such as were grown to credit by the wars;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Not fearing death, nor shrinking for distress,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But always resolute in most extremes.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: He then that is not furnishd in this sort

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Doth but usurp the sacred name of knight,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Profaning this most honourable order,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And should, if I were worthy to be judge,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Be quite degraded, like a hedge-born swain

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That doth presume to boast of gentle blood.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Stain to thy countrymen, thou hearst thy doom!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Be packing, therefore, thou that wast a knight:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Henceforth we banish thee, on pain of death.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Exit FASTOLFE

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And now, my lord protector, view the letter

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Sent from our uncle Duke of Burgundy.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What means his grace, that he hath changed his style?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: No more but, plain and bluntly, To the king!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Hath he forgot he is his sovereign?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or doth this churlish superscription

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Pretend some alteration in good will?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Whats here?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Reads

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I have, upon especial cause,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Moved with compassion of my countrys wreck,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Together with the pitiful complaints

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Of such as your oppression feeds upon,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Forsaken your pernicious faction

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And joind with Charles, the rightful King of France.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O monstrous treachery! can this be so,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That in alliance, amity and oaths,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: There should be found such false dissembling guile?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What! doth my uncle Burgundy revolt?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He doth, my lord, and is become your foe.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Is that the worst this letter doth contain?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: It is the worst, and all, my lord, he writes.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Why, then, Lord Talbot there shall talk with him

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And give him chastisement for this abuse.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How say you, my lord? are you not content?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Content, my liege! yes, but that I am prevented,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I should have beggd I might have been employd.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Then gather strength and march unto him straight:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Let him perceive how ill we brook his treason

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And what offence it is to flout his friends.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I go, my lord, in heart desiring still

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: You may behold confusion of your foes.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Enter VERNON and BASSET

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Grant me the combat, gracious sovereign.

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: And me, my lord, grant me the combat too.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: This is my servant: hear him, noble prince.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And this is mine: sweet Henry, favour him.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Be patient, lords; and give them leave to speak.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Say, gentlemen, what makes you thus exclaim?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And wherefore crave you combat? or with whom?

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: With him, my lord; for he hath done me wrong.

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: And I with him; for he hath done me wrong.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What is that wrong whereof you both complain?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: First let me know, and then Ill answer you.

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Crossing the sea from England into France,

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: This fellow here, with envious carping tongue,

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Upbraided me about the rose I wear;

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Saying, the sanguine colour of the leaves

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Did represent my masters blushing cheeks,

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: When stubbornly he did repugn the truth

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: About a certain question in the law

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Argued betwixt the Duke of York and him;

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: With other vile and ignominious terms:

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: In confutation of which rude reproach

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: And in defence of my lords worthiness,

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: I crave the benefit of law of arms.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: And that is my petition, noble lord:

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: For though he seem with forged quaint conceit

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: To set a gloss upon his bold intent,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Yet know, my lord, I was provoked by him;

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: And he first took exceptions at this badge,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Pronouncing that the paleness of this flower

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Bewrayd the faintness of my masters heart.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Will not this malice, Somerset, be left?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Your private grudge, my Lord of York, will out,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Though neer so cunningly you smother it.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Good Lord, what madness rules in brainsick men,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When for so slight and frivolous a cause

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Such factious emulations shall arise!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Good cousins both, of York and Somerset,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Quiet yourselves, I pray, and be at peace.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Let this dissension first be tried by fight,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And then your highness shall command a peace.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: The quarrel toucheth none but us alone;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Betwixt ourselves let us decide it then.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: There is my pledge; accept it, Somerset.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Nay, let it rest where it began at first.

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Confirm it so, mine honourable lord.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Confirm it so! Confounded be your strife!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And perish ye, with your audacious prate!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Presumptuous vassals, are you not ashamed

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: With this immodest clamorous outrage

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To trouble and disturb the king and us?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And you, my lords, methinks you do not well

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To bear with their perverse objections;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Much less to take occasion from their mouths

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To raise a mutiny betwixt yourselves:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Let me persuade you take a better course.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: It grieves his highness: good my lords, be friends.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Come hither, you that would be combatants:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Henceforth I charge you, as you love our favour,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Quite to forget this quarrel and the cause.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And you, my lords, remember where we are,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: In France, amongst a fickle wavering nation:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If they perceive dissension in our looks

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And that within ourselves we disagree,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How will their grudging stomachs be provoked

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To wilful disobedience, and rebel!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Beside, what infamy will there arise,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When foreign princes shall be certified

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That for a toy, a thing of no regard,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: King Henrys peers and chief nobility

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Destroyd themselves, and lost the realm of France!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, think upon the conquest of my father,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My tender years, and let us not forego

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That for a trifle that was bought with blood

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Let me be umpire in this doubtful strife.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I see no reason, if I wear this rose,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Putting on a red rose

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That any one should therefore be suspicious

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I more incline to Somerset than York:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Both are my kinsmen, and I love them both:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: As well they may upbraid me with my crown,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Because, forsooth, the king of Scots is crownd.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But your discretions better can persuade

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Than I am able to instruct or teach:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And therefore, as we hither came in peace,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So let us still continue peace and love.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Cousin of York, we institute your grace

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To be our regent in these parts of France:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And, good my Lord of Somerset, unite

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Your troops of horsemen with his bands of foot;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And, like true subjects, sons of your progenitors,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Go cheerfully together and digest.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Your angry choler on your enemies.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ourself, my lord protector and the rest

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: After some respite will return to Calais;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: From thence to England; where I hope ere long

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To be presented, by your victories,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: With Charles, Alencon and that traitorous rout.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt all but YORK, WARWICK, EXETER and VERNON

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: My Lord of York, I promise you, the king

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Prettily, methought, did play the orator.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And so he did; but yet I like it not,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: In that he wears the badge of Somerset.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Tush, that was but his fancy, blame him not;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I dare presume, sweet prince, he thought no harm.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: An if I wist he did,--but let it rest;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Other affairs must now be managed.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Exeunt all but EXETER

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Well didst thou, Richard, to suppress thy voice;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: For, had the passions of thy heart burst out,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: I fear we should have seen decipherd there

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: More rancorous spite, more furious raging broils,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Than yet can be imagined or supposed.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: But howsoeer, no simple man that sees

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: This jarring discord of nobility,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: This shouldering of each other in the court,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: This factious bandying of their favourites,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: But that it doth presage some ill event.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Tis much when sceptres are in childrens hands;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: But more when envy breeds unkind division;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: There comes the rain, there begins confusion.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: SCENE II. Before Bourdeaux.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Enter TALBOT, with trump and drum

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Go to the gates of Bourdeaux, trumpeter:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Summon their general unto the wall.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Trumpet sounds. Enter General and others, aloft

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: English John Talbot, captains, calls you forth,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Servant in arms to Harry King of England;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And thus he would: Open your city gates;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Be humble to us; call my sovereign yours,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And do him homage as obedient subjects;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And Ill withdraw me and my bloody power:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But, if you frown upon this profferd peace,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: You tempt the fury of my three attendants,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Lean famine, quartering steel, and climbing fire;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Who in a moment even with the earth

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Shall lay your stately and air-braving towers,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: If you forsake the offer of their love.

speaker: General
text_entry: Thou ominous and fearful owl of death,

speaker: General
text_entry: Our nations terror and their bloody scourge!

speaker: General
text_entry: The period of thy tyranny approacheth.

speaker: General
text_entry: On us thou canst not enter but by death;

speaker: General
text_entry: For, I protest, we are well fortified

speaker: General
text_entry: And strong enough to issue out and fight:

speaker: General
text_entry: If thou retire, the Dauphin, well appointed,

speaker: General
text_entry: Stands with the snares of war to tangle thee:

speaker: General
text_entry: On either hand thee there are squadrons pitchd,

speaker: General
text_entry: To wall thee from the liberty of flight;

speaker: General
text_entry: And no way canst thou turn thee for redress,

speaker: General
text_entry: But death doth front thee with apparent spoil

speaker: General
text_entry: And pale destruction meets thee in the face.

speaker: General
text_entry: Ten thousand French have taen the sacrament

speaker: General
text_entry: To rive their dangerous artillery

speaker: General
text_entry: Upon no Christian soul but English Talbot.

speaker: General
text_entry: Lo, there thou standst, a breathing valiant man,

speaker: General
text_entry: Of an invincible unconquerd spirit!

speaker: General
text_entry: This is the latest glory of thy praise

speaker: General
text_entry: That I, thy enemy, due thee withal;

speaker: General
text_entry: For ere the glass, that now begins to run,

speaker: General
text_entry: Finish the process of his sandy hour,

speaker: General
text_entry: These eyes, that see thee now well coloured,

speaker: General
text_entry: Shall see thee witherd, bloody, pale and dead.

speaker: General
text_entry: Drum afar off

speaker: General
text_entry: Hark! hark! the Dauphins drum, a warning bell,

speaker: General
text_entry: Sings heavy music to thy timorous soul;

speaker: General
text_entry: And mine shall ring thy dire departure out.

speaker: General
text_entry: Exeunt General,  and c

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: He fables not; I hear the enemy:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Out, some light horsemen, and peruse their wings.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: O, negligent and heedless discipline!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: How are we parkd and bounded in a pale,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A little herd of Englands timorous deer,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Mazed with a yelping kennel of French curs!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: If we be English deer, be then in blood;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Not rascal-like, to fall down with a pinch,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But rather, moody-mad and desperate stags,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Turn on the bloody hounds with heads of steel

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And make the cowards stand aloof at bay:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Sell every man his life as dear as mine,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And they shall find dear deer of us, my friends.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: God and Saint George, Talbot and Englands right,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Prosper our colours in this dangerous fight!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: SCENE III. Plains in Gascony.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Enter a Messenger that meets YORK. Enter YORK with trumpet and many Soldiers

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Are not the speedy scouts returnd again,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That doggd the mighty army of the Dauphin?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: They are returnd, my lord, and give it out

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: That he is marchd to Bourdeaux with his power,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: To fight with Talbot: as he marchd along,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: By your espials were discovered

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Two mightier troops than that the Dauphin led,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Which joind with him and made their march for Bourdeaux.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: A plague upon that villain Somerset,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That thus delays my promised supply

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Of horsemen, that were levied for this siege!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Renowned Talbot doth expect my aid,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And I am lowted by a traitor villain

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And cannot help the noble chevalier:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: God comfort him in this necessity!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: If he miscarry, farewell wars in France.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter Sir William LUCY

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Thou princely leader of our English strength,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Never so needful on the earth of France,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Spur to the rescue of the noble Talbot,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Who now is girdled with a waist of iron

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And hemmd about with grim destruction:

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: To Bourdeaux, warlike duke! to Bourdeaux, York!

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Else, farewell Talbot, France, and Englands honour.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: O God, that Somerset, who in proud heart

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Doth stop my cornets, were in Talbots place!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: So should we save a valiant gentleman

speaker: YORK
text_entry: By forfeiting a traitor and a coward.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Mad ire and wrathful fury makes me weep,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That thus we die, while remiss traitors sleep.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: O, send some succor to the distressd lord!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: He dies, we lose; I break my warlike word;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: We mourn, France smiles; we lose, they daily get;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: All long of this vile traitor Somerset.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Then God take mercy on brave Talbots soul;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And on his son young John, who two hours since

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: I met in travel toward his warlike father!

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: This seven years did not Talbot see his son;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And now they meet where both their lives are done.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Alas, what joy shall noble Talbot have

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To bid his young son welcome to his grave?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Away! vexation almost stops my breath,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That sunderd friends greet in the hour of death.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Lucy, farewell; no more my fortune can,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But curse the cause I cannot aid the man.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Maine, Blois, Poictiers, and Tours, are won away,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Long all of Somerset and his delay.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Exit, with his soldiers

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Thus, while the vulture of sedition

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Feeds in the bosom of such great commanders,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Sleeping neglection doth betray to loss

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: The conquest of our scarce cold conqueror,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: That ever living man of memory,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Henry the Fifth: whiles they each other cross,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Lives, honours, lands and all hurry to loss.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: SCENE IV. Other plains in Gascony.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Enter SOMERSET, with his army; a Captain of TALBOTs with him

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: It is too late; I cannot send them now:

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: This expedition was by York and Talbot

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Too rashly plotted: all our general force

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Might with a sally of the very town

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Be buckled with: the over-daring Talbot

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Hath sullied all his gloss of former honour

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: By this unheedful, desperate, wild adventure:

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: York set him on to fight and die in shame,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: That, Talbot dead, great York might bear the name.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Here is Sir William Lucy, who with me

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Set from our oermatchd forces forth for aid.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Enter Sir William LUCY

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: How now, Sir William! whither were you sent?

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Whither, my lord? from bought and sold Lord Talbot;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Who, ringd about with bold adversity,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Cries out for noble York and Somerset,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: To beat assailing death from his weak legions:

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And whiles the honourable captain there

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Drops bloody sweat from his war-wearied limbs,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And, in advantage lingering, looks for rescue,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: You, his false hopes, the trust of Englands honour,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Keep off aloof with worthless emulation.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Let not your private discord keep away

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: The levied succors that should lend him aid,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: While he, renowned noble gentleman,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Yields up his life unto a world of odds:

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Orleans the Bastard, Charles, Burgundy,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Alencon, Reignier, compass him about,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And Talbot perisheth by your default.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: York set him on; York should have sent him aid.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And York as fast upon your grace exclaims;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Swearing that you withhold his levied host,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Collected for this expedition.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: York lies; he might have sent and had the horse;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: I owe him little duty, and less love;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And take foul scorn to fawn on him by sending.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: The fraud of England, not the force of France,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Hath now entrappd the noble-minded Talbot:

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Never to England shall he bear his life;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: But dies, betrayd to fortune by your strife.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Come, go; I will dispatch the horsemen straight:

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Within six hours they will be at his aid.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Too late comes rescue: he is taen or slain;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: For fly he could not, if he would have fled;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And fly would Talbot never, though he might.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: If he be dead, brave Talbot, then adieu!

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: His fame lives in the world, his shame in you.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: SCENE V. The English camp near Bourdeaux.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Enter TALBOT and JOHN his son

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: O young John Talbot! I did send for thee

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: To tutor thee in stratagems of war,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That Talbots name might be in thee revived

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: When sapless age and weak unable limbs

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Should bring thy father to his drooping chair.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But, O malignant and ill-boding stars!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Now thou art come unto a feast of death,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A terrible and unavoided danger:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Therefore, dear boy, mount on my swiftest horse;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And Ill direct thee how thou shalt escape

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: By sudden flight: come, dally not, be gone.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Is my name Talbot? and am I your son?

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: And shall I fly? O if you love my mother,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Dishonour not her honourable name,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: To make a bastard and a slave of me!

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: The world will say, he is not Talbots blood,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: That basely fled when noble Talbot stood.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Fly, to revenge my death, if I be slain.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: He that flies so will neer return again.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: If we both stay, we both are sure to die.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Then let me stay; and, father, do you fly:

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Your loss is great, so your regard should be;

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: My worth unknown, no loss is known in me.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Upon my death the French can little boast;

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: In yours they will, in you all hopes are lost.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Flight cannot stain the honour you have won;

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: But mine it will, that no exploit have done:

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: You fled for vantage, everyone will swear;

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: But, if I bow, theyll say it was for fear.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: There is no hope that ever I will stay,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: If the first hour I shrink and run away.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Here on my knee I beg mortality,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Rather than life preserved with infamy.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Shall all thy mothers hopes lie in one tomb?

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Ay, rather than Ill shame my mothers womb.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Upon my blessing, I command thee go.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: To fight I will, but not to fly the foe.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Part of thy father may be saved in thee.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: No part of him but will be shame in me.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Thou never hadst renown, nor canst not lose it.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Yes, your renowned name: shall flight abuse it?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Thy fathers charge shall clear thee from that stain.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: You cannot witness for me, being slain.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: If death be so apparent, then both fly.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And leave my followers here to fight and die?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: My age was never tainted with such shame.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: And shall my youth be guilty of such blame?

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: No more can I be severd from your side,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Than can yourself yourself in twain divide:

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Stay, go, do what you will, the like do I;

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: For live I will not, if my father die.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Then here I take my leave of thee, fair son,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Born to eclipse thy life this afternoon.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Come, side by side together live and die.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And soul with soul from France to heaven fly.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: SCENE VI. A field of battle.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Alarum: excursions, wherein JOHN TALBOT is hemmed about, and TALBOT rescues him

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Saint George and victory! fight, soldiers, fight.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The regent hath with Talbot broke his word

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And left us to the rage of France his sword.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Where is John Talbot? Pause, and take thy breath;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I gave thee life and rescued thee from death.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: O, twice my father, twice am I thy son!

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: The life thou gavest me first was lost and done,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Till with thy warlike sword, despite of late,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: To my determined time thou gavest new date.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: When from the Dauphins crest thy sword struck fire,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: It warmd thy fathers heart with proud desire

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Of bold-faced victory. Then leaden age,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Quickend with youthful spleen and warlike rage,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Beat down Alencon, Orleans, Burgundy,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And from the pride of Gallia rescued thee.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The ireful bastard Orleans, that drew blood

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: From thee, my boy, and had the maidenhood

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Of thy first fight, I soon encountered,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And interchanging blows I quickly shed

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Some of his bastard blood; and in disgrace

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Bespoke him thus; Contaminated, base

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And misbegotten blood I spill of thine,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Mean and right poor, for that pure blood of mine

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Which thou didst force from Talbot, my brave boy:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Here, purposing the Bastard to destroy,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Came in strong rescue. Speak, thy fathers care,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Art thou not weary, John? how dost thou fare?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Wilt thou yet leave the battle, boy, and fly,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Now thou art seald the son of chivalry?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Fly, to revenge my death when I am dead:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The help of one stands me in little stead.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: O, too much folly is it, well I wot,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: To hazard all our lives in one small boat!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: If I to-day die not with Frenchmens rage,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: To-morrow I shall die with mickle age:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: By me they nothing gain an if I stay;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Tis but the shortening of my life one day:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In thee thy mother dies, our households name,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: My deaths revenge, thy youth, and Englands fame:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: All these and more we hazard by thy stay;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: All these are saved if thou wilt fly away.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: The sword of Orleans hath not made me smart;

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: These words of yours draw life-blood from my heart:

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: On that advantage, bought with such a shame,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: To save a paltry life and slay bright fame,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Before young Talbot from old Talbot fly,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: The coward horse that bears me fail and die!

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: And like me to the peasant boys of France,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: To be shames scorn and subject of mischance!

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Surely, by all the glory you have won,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: An if I fly, I am not Talbots son:

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Then talk no more of flight, it is no boot;

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: If son to Talbot, die at Talbots foot.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Then follow thou thy desperate sire of Crete,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Thou Icarus; thy life to me is sweet:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: If thou wilt fight, fight by thy fathers side;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And, commendable proved, lets die in pride.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: SCENE VII. Another part of the field.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Alarum: excursions. Enter TALBOT led by a Servant

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Where is my other life? mine own is gone;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: O, wheres young Talbot? where is valiant John?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Triumphant death, smeard with captivity,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Young Talbots valour makes me smile at thee:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: When he perceived me shrink and on my knee,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: His bloody sword he brandishd over me,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And, like a hungry lion, did commence

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Rough deeds of rage and stern impatience;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But when my angry guardant stood alone,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Tendering my ruin and assaild of none,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Dizzy-eyed fury and great rage of heart

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Suddenly made him from my side to start

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Into the clustering battle of the French;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And in that sea of blood my boy did drench

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: His over-mounting spirit, and there died,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: My Icarus, my blossom, in his pride.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: O, my dear lord, lo, where your son is borne!

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Enter Soldiers, with the body of JOHN TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Thou antic death, which laughst us here to scorn,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Anon, from thy insulting tyranny,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Coupled in bonds of perpetuity,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Two Talbots, winged through the lither sky,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In thy despite shall scape mortality.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: O, thou, whose wounds become hard-favourd death,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Speak to thy father ere thou yield thy breath!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Brave death by speaking, whether he will or no;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Imagine him a Frenchman and thy foe.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Poor boy! he smiles, methinks, as who should say,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Had death been French, then death had died to-day.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Come, come and lay him in his fathers arms:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: My spirit can no longer bear these harms.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Soldiers, adieu! I have what I would have,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Now my old arms are young John Talbots grave.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Dies

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Enter CHARLES, ALENCON, BURGUNDY, BASTARD OF ORLEANS, JOAN LA PUCELLE, and forces

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Had York and Somerset brought rescue in,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: We should have found a bloody day of this.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: How the young whelp of Talbots, raging-wood,

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Did flesh his puny sword in Frenchmens blood!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Once I encounterd him, and thus I said:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Thou maiden youth, be vanquishd by a maid:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: But, with a proud majestical high scorn,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: He answerd thus: Young Talbot was not born

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: To be the pillage of a giglot wench:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: So, rushing in the bowels of the French,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: He left me proudly, as unworthy fight.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Doubtless he would have made a noble knight;

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: See, where he lies inhearsed in the arms

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Of the most bloody nurser of his harms!

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Hew them to pieces, hack their bones asunder

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Whose life was Englands glory, Gallias wonder.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: O, no, forbear! for that which we have fled

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: During the life, let us not wrong it dead.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Enter Sir William LUCY, attended; Herald of the French preceding

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Herald, conduct me to the Dauphins tent,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: To know who hath obtained the glory of the day.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: On what submissive message art thou sent?

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Submission, Dauphin! tis a mere French word;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: We English warriors wot not what it means.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: I come to know what prisoners thou hast taen

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And to survey the bodies of the dead.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: For prisoners askst thou? hell our prison is.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: But tell me whom thou seekst.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: But wheres the great Alcides of the field,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Valiant Lord Talbot, Earl of Shrewsbury,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Created, for his rare success in arms,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Great Earl of Washford, Waterford and Valence;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Lord Talbot of Goodrig and Urchinfield,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Lord Strange of Blackmere, Lord Verdun of Alton,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Lord Cromwell of Wingfield, Lord Furnival of Sheffield,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: The thrice-victorious Lord of Falconbridge;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Knight of the noble order of Saint George,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Worthy Saint Michael and the Golden Fleece;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Great marshal to Henry the Sixth

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Of all his wars within the realm of France?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Here is a silly stately style indeed!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: The Turk, that two and fifty kingdoms hath,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Writes not so tedious a style as this.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Him that thou magnifiest with all these titles

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Stinking and fly-blown lies here at our feet.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Is Talbot slain, the Frenchmens only scourge,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Your kingdoms terror and black Nemesis?

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: O, were mine eyeballs into bullets turnd,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: That I in rage might shoot them at your faces!

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: O, that I could but call these dead to life!

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: It were enough to fright the realm of France:

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Were but his picture left amongst you here,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: It would amaze the proudest of you all.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Give me their bodies, that I may bear them hence

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And give them burial as beseems their worth.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I think this upstart is old Talbots ghost,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: He speaks with such a proud commanding spirit.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: For Gods sake let him have em; to keep them here,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: They would but stink, and putrefy the air.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Go, take their bodies hence.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Ill bear them hence; but from their ashes shall be reard

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: A phoenix that shall make all France afeard.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: So we be rid of them, do with em what thou wilt.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And now to Paris, in this conquering vein:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: All will be ours, now bloody Talbots slain.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: SCENE I. London. The palace.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Sennet. Enter KING HENRY VI, GLOUCESTER, and EXETER

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Have you perused the letters from the pope,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The emperor and the Earl of Armagnac?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I have, my lord: and their intent is this:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: They humbly sue unto your excellence

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To have a godly peace concluded of

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Between the realms of England and of France.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How doth your grace affect their motion?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Well, my good lord; and as the only means

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To stop effusion of our Christian blood

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And stablish quietness on every side.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ay, marry, uncle; for I always thought

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: It was both impious and unnatural

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That such immanity and bloody strife

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Should reign among professors of one faith.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Beside, my lord, the sooner to effect

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And surer bind this knot of amity,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The Earl of Armagnac, near knit to Charles,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A man of great authority in France,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Proffers his only daughter to your grace

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: In marriage, with a large and sumptuous dowry.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Marriage, uncle! alas, my years are young!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And fitter is my study and my books

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Than wanton dalliance with a paramour.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Yet call the ambassador; and, as you please,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So let them have their answers every one:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I shall be well content with any choice

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Tends to Gods glory and my countrys weal.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enter CARDINAL OF WINCHESTER in Cardinals habit, a Legate and two Ambassadors

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: What! is my Lord of Winchester installd,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And calld unto a cardinals degree?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Then I perceive that will be verified

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Henry the Fifth did sometime prophesy,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: If once he come to be a cardinal,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Hell make his cap co-equal with the crown.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My lords ambassadors, your several suits

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Have been considerd and debated on.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And therefore are we certainly resolved

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To draw conditions of a friendly peace;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Which by my Lord of Winchester we mean

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Shall be transported presently to France.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And for the proffer of my lord your master,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I have informd his highness so at large

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As liking of the ladys virtuous gifts,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Her beauty and the value of her dower,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He doth intend she shall be Englands queen.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: In argument and proof of which contract,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Bear her this jewel, pledge of my affection.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And so, my lord protector, see them guarded

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And safely brought to Dover; where inshippd

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Commit them to the fortune of the sea.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Exeunt all but CARDINAL OF WINCHESTER and Legate

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: CARDINAL

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Stay, my lord legate: you shall first receive

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: The sum of money which I promised

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Should be deliverd to his holiness

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: For clothing me in these grave ornaments.

speaker: Legate
text_entry: I will attend upon your lordships leisure.

speaker: Legate
text_entry: CARDINAL

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  Now Winchester will not submit, I trow,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Or be inferior to the proudest peer.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Humphrey of Gloucester, thou shalt well perceive

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: That, neither in birth or for authority,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: The bishop will be overborne by thee:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Ill either make thee stoop and bend thy knee,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Or sack this country with a mutiny.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: SCENE II. France. Plains in Anjou.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Enter CHARLES, BURGUNDY, ALENCON, BASTARD OF ORLEANS, REIGNIER, JOAN LA PUCELLE, and forces

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: These news, my lord, may cheer our drooping spirits:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Tis said the stout Parisians do revolt

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And turn again unto the warlike French.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Then march to Paris, royal Charles of France,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: And keep not back your powers in dalliance.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Peace be amongst them, if they turn to us;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Else, ruin combat with their palaces!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Enter Scout

speaker: Scout
text_entry: Success unto our valiant general,

speaker: Scout
text_entry: And happiness to his accomplices!

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: What tidings send our scouts? I prithee, speak.

speaker: Scout
text_entry: The English army, that divided was

speaker: Scout
text_entry: Into two parties, is now conjoined in one,

speaker: Scout
text_entry: And means to give you battle presently.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Somewhat too sudden, sirs, the warning is;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: But we will presently provide for them.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: I trust the ghost of Talbot is not there:

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Now he is gone, my lord, you need not fear.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Of all base passions, fear is most accursed.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Command the conquest, Charles, it shall be thine,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Let Henry fret and all the world repine.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Then on, my lords; and France be fortunate!

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: SCENE III. Before Angiers.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Alarum. Excursions. Enter JOAN LA PUCELLE

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: The regent conquers, and the Frenchmen fly.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Now help, ye charming spells and periapts;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And ye choice spirits that admonish me

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And give me signs of future accidents.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Thunder

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: You speedy helpers, that are substitutes

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Under the lordly monarch of the north,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Appear and aid me in this enterprise.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Enter Fiends

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: This speedy and quick appearance argues proof

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Of your accustomd diligence to me.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Now, ye familiar spirits, that are culld

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Out of the powerful regions under earth,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Help me this once, that France may get the field.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: They walk, and speak not

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: O, hold me not with silence over-long!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Where I was wont to feed you with my blood,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Ill lop a member off and give it you

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: In earnest of further benefit,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: So you do condescend to help me now.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: They hang their heads

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: No hope to have redress? My body shall

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Pay recompense, if you will grant my suit.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: They shake their heads

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Cannot my body nor blood-sacrifice

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Entreat you to your wonted furtherance?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Then take my soul, my body, soul and all,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Before that England give the French the foil.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: They depart

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: See, they forsake me! Now the time is come

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: That France must vail her lofty-plumed crest

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And let her head fall into Englands lap.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: My ancient incantations are too weak,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And hell too strong for me to buckle with:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Now, France, thy glory droopeth to the dust.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Excursions. Re-enter JOAN LA PUCELLE fighting hand  to hand with YORK. JOAN LA PUCELLE is taken. The French fly.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Damsel of France, I think I have you fast:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Unchain your spirits now with spelling charms

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And try if they can gain your liberty.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: A goodly prize, fit for the devils grace!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: See, how the ugly wench doth bend her brows,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: As if with Circe she would change my shape!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Changed to a worser shape thou canst not be.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: O, Charles the Dauphin is a proper man;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: No shape but his can please your dainty eye.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: A plaguing mischief light on Charles and thee!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And may ye both be suddenly surprised

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: By bloody hands, in sleeping on your beds!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Fell banning hag, enchantress, hold thy tongue!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I prithee, give me leave to curse awhile.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Curse, miscreant, when thou comest to the stake.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Alarum. Enter SUFFOLK with MARGARET in his hand

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Be what thou wilt, thou art my prisoner.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Gazes on her

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: O fairest beauty, do not fear nor fly!

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: For I will touch thee but with reverent hands;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: I kiss these fingers for eternal peace,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And lay them gently on thy tender side.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Who art thou? say, that I may honour thee.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Margaret my name, and daughter to a king,

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: The King of Naples, whosoeer thou art.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: An earl I am, and Suffolk am I calld.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Be not offended, natures miracle,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Thou art allotted to be taen by me:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: So doth the swan her downy cygnets save,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Keeping them prisoner underneath her wings.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Yet, if this servile usage once offend.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Go, and be free again, as Suffolks friend.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: She is going

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: O, stay! I have no power to let her pass;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: My hand would free her, but my heart says no

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: As plays the sun upon the glassy streams,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Twinkling another counterfeited beam,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: So seems this gorgeous beauty to mine eyes.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Fain would I woo her, yet I dare not speak:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Ill call for pen and ink, and write my mind.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Fie, de la Pole! disable not thyself;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Hast not a tongue? is she not here?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Wilt thou be daunted at a womans sight?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Ay, beautys princely majesty is such,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Confounds the tongue and makes the senses rough.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Say, Earl of Suffolk--if thy name be so--

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: What ransom must I pay before I pass?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: For I perceive I am thy prisoner.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: How canst thou tell she will deny thy suit,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Before thou make a trial of her love?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Why speakst thou not? what ransom must I pay?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Shes beautiful, and therefore to be wood;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: She is a woman, therefore to be won.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Wilt thou accept of ransom? yea, or no.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Fond man, remember that thou hast a wife;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Then how can Margaret be thy paramour?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: I were best to leave him, for he will not hear.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: There all is marrd; there lies a cooling card.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: He talks at random; sure, the man is mad.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And yet a dispensation may be had.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: And yet I would that you would answer me.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Ill win this Lady Margaret. For whom?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Why, for my king: tush, thats a wooden thing!

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: He talks of wood: it is some carpenter.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Yet so my fancy may be satisfied,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And peace established between these realms

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: But there remains a scruple in that too;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: For though her father be the King of Naples,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Duke of Anjou and Maine, yet is he poor,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And our nobility will scorn the match.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Hear ye, captain, are you not at leisure?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: It shall be so, disdain they neer so much.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Henry is youthful and will quickly yield.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Madam, I have a secret to reveal.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: What though I be enthralld? he seems a knight,

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: And will not any way dishonour me.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Lady, vouchsafe to listen what I say.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Perhaps I shall be rescued by the French;

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: And then I need not crave his courtesy.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Sweet madam, give me a hearing in a cause--

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Tush, women have been captivate ere now.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Lady, wherefore talk you so?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: I cry you mercy, tis but Quid for Quo.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Say, gentle princess, would you not suppose

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Your bondage happy, to be made a queen?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: To be a queen in bondage is more vile

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Than is a slave in base servility;

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: For princes should be free.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And so shall you,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: If happy Englands royal king be free.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Why, what concerns his freedom unto me?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Ill undertake to make thee Henrys queen,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: To put a golden sceptre in thy hand

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And set a precious crown upon thy head,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: If thou wilt condescend to be my--

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: What?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: His love.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: I am unworthy to be Henrys wife.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: No, gentle madam; I unworthy am

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: To woo so fair a dame to be his wife,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And have no portion in the choice myself.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: How say you, madam, are ye so content?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: An if my father please, I am content.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Then call our captains and our colours forth.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And, madam, at your fathers castle walls

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Well crave a parley, to confer with him.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: A parley sounded. Enter REIGNIER on the walls

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: See, Reignier, see, thy daughter prisoner!

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: To whom?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: To me.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Suffolk, what remedy?

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: I am a soldier, and unapt to weep,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Or to exclaim on fortunes fickleness.

speaker: SU FFOLK
text_entry: Yes, there is remedy enough, my lord:

speaker: SU FFOLK
text_entry: Consent, and for thy honour give consent,

speaker: SU FFOLK
text_entry: Thy daughter shall be wedded to my king;

speaker: SU FFOLK
text_entry: Whom I with pain have wood and won thereto;

speaker: SU FFOLK
text_entry: And this her easy-held imprisonment

speaker: SU FFOLK
text_entry: Hath gained thy daughter princely liberty.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Speaks Suffolk as he thinks?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Fair Margaret knows

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: That Suffolk doth not flatter, face, or feign.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Upon thy princely warrant, I descend

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: To give thee answer of thy just demand.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Exit from the walls

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And here I will expect thy coming.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Trumpets sound. Enter REIGNIER, below

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Welcome, brave earl, into our territories:

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Command in Anjou what your honour pleases.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Thanks, Reignier, happy for so sweet a child,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Fit to be made companion with a king:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: What answer makes your grace unto my suit?

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Since thou dost deign to woo her little worth

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: To be the princely bride of such a lord;

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Upon condition I may quietly

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Enjoy mine own, the country Maine and Anjou,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Free from oppression or the stroke of war,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: My daughter shall be Henrys, if he please.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: That is her ransom; I deliver her;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And those two counties I will undertake

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Your grace shall well and quietly enjoy.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: And I again, in Henrys royal name,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: As deputy unto that gracious king,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Give thee her hand, for sign of plighted faith.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Reignier of France, I give thee kingly thanks,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Because this is in traffic of a king.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Aside

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And yet, methinks, I could be well content

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: To be mine own attorney in this case.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Ill over then to England with this news,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And make this marriage to be solemnized.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: So farewell, Reignier: set this diamond safe

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: In golden palaces, as it becomes.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: I do embrace thee, as I would embrace

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: The Christian prince, King Henry, were he here.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Farewell, my lord: good wishes, praise and prayers

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Shall Suffolk ever have of Margaret.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Going

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Farewell, sweet madam: but hark you, Margaret;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: No princely commendations to my king?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Such commendations as becomes a maid,

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: A virgin and his servant, say to him.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Words sweetly placed and modestly directed.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: But madam, I must trouble you again;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: No loving token to his majesty?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Yes, my good lord, a pure unspotted heart,

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Never yet taint with love, I send the king.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And this withal.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Kisses her

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: That for thyself: I will not so presume

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: To send such peevish tokens to a king.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Exeunt REIGNIER and MARGARET

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: O, wert thou for myself! But, Suffolk, stay;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Thou mayst not wander in that labyrinth;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: There Minotaurs and ugly treasons lurk.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Solicit Henry with her wondrous praise:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Bethink thee on her virtues that surmount,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And natural graces that extinguish art;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Repeat their semblance often on the seas,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: That, when thou comest to kneel at Henrys feet,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Thou mayst bereave him of his wits with wonder.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: SCENE IV. Camp of the YORK in Anjou.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Enter YORK, WARWICK, and others

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Bring forth that sorceress condemnd to burn.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter JOAN LA PUCELLE, guarded, and a Shepherd

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Ah, Joan, this kills thy fathers heart outright!

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Have I sought every country far and near,

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: And, now it is my chance to find thee out,

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Must I behold thy timeless cruel death?

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Ah, Joan, sweet daughter Joan, Ill die with thee!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Decrepit miser! base ignoble wretch!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I am descended of a gentler blood:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Thou art no father nor no friend of mine.

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Out, out! My lords, an please you, tis not so;

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: I did beget her, all the parish knows:

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Her mother liveth yet, can testify

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: She was the first fruit of my bachelorship.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Graceless! wilt thou deny thy parentage?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: This argues what her kind of life hath been,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Wicked and vile; and so her death concludes.

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Fie, Joan, that thou wilt be so obstacle!

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: God knows thou art a collop of my flesh;

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: And for thy sake have I shed many a tear:

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Deny me not, I prithee, gentle Joan.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Peasant, avaunt! You have subornd this man,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Of purpose to obscure my noble birth.

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Tis true, I gave a noble to the priest

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: The morn that I was wedded to her mother.

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Kneel down and take my blessing, good my girl.

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Wilt thou not stoop? Now cursed be the time

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Of thy nativity! I would the milk

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Thy mother gave thee when thou suckdst her breast,

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Had been a little ratsbane for thy sake!

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Or else, when thou didst keep my lambs a-field,

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: I wish some ravenous wolf had eaten thee!

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Dost thou deny thy father, cursed drab?

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: O, burn her, burn her! hanging is too good.

speaker: Shepherd
text_entry: Exit

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Take her away; for she hath lived too long,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To fill the world with vicious qualities.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: First, let me tell you whom you have condemnd:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Not me begotten of a shepherd swain,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: But issued from the progeny of kings;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Virtuous and holy; chosen from above,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: By inspiration of celestial grace,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: To work exceeding miracles on earth.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I never had to do with wicked spirits:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: But you, that are polluted with your lusts,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Staind with the guiltless blood of innocents,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Corrupt and tainted with a thousand vices,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Because you want the grace that others have,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: You judge it straight a thing impossible

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: To compass wonders but by help of devils.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: No, misconceived! Joan of Arc hath been

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: A virgin from her tender infancy,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Chaste and immaculate in very thought;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Whose maiden blood, thus rigorously effused,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Will cry for vengeance at the gates of heaven.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Ay, ay: away with her to execution!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And hark ye, sirs; because she is a maid,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Spare for no faggots, let there be enow:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Place barrels of pitch upon the fatal stake,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That so her torture may be shortened.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Will nothing turn your unrelenting hearts?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Then, Joan, discover thine infirmity,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: That warranteth by law to be thy privilege.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I am with child, ye bloody homicides:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Murder not then the fruit within my womb,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Although ye hale me to a violent death.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Now heaven forfend! the holy maid with child!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The greatest miracle that eer ye wrought:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Is all your strict preciseness come to this?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: She and the Dauphin have been juggling:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I did imagine what would be her refuge.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Well, go to; well have no bastards live;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Especially since Charles must father it.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: You are deceived; my child is none of his:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: It was Alencon that enjoyd my love.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Alencon! that notorious Machiavel!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: It dies, an if it had a thousand lives.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: O, give me leave, I have deluded you:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Twas neither Charles nor yet the duke I named,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: But Reignier, king of Naples, that prevaild.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: A married man! thats most intolerable.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Why, heres a girl! I think she knows not well,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: There were so many, whom she may accuse.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Its sign she hath been liberal and free.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And yet, forsooth, she is a virgin pure.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Strumpet, thy words condemn thy brat and thee:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Use no entreaty, for it is in vain.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Then lead me hence; with whom I leave my curse:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: May never glorious sun reflex his beams

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Upon the country where you make abode;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: But darkness and the gloomy shade of death

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Environ you, till mischief and despair

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Drive you to break your necks or hang yourselves!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Exit, guarded

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Break thou in pieces and consume to ashes,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thou foul accursed minister of hell!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter CARDINAL OF WINCHESTER, attended

speaker: YORK
text_entry: CARDINAL

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Lord regent, I do greet your excellence

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: With letters of commission from the king.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: For know, my lords, the states of Christendom,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Moved with remorse of these outrageous broils,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Have earnestly implored a general peace

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Betwixt our nation and the aspiring French;

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And here at hand the Dauphin and his train

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Approacheth, to confer about some matter.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Is all our travail turnd to this effect?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: After the slaughter of so many peers,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: So many captains, gentlemen and soldiers,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That in this quarrel have been overthrown

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And sold their bodies for their countrys benefit,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Shall we at last conclude effeminate peace?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Have we not lost most part of all the towns,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: By treason, falsehood and by treachery,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Our great progenitors had conquered?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: O Warwick, Warwick! I foresee with grief

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The utter loss of all the realm of France.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Be patient, York: if we conclude a peace,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: It shall be with such strict and severe covenants

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: As little shall the Frenchmen gain thereby.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter CHARLES, ALENCON, BASTARD OF ORLEANS, REIGNIER, and others

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Since, lords of England, it is thus agreed

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: That peaceful truce shall be proclaimd in France,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: We come to be informed by yourselves

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: What the conditions of that league must be.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Speak, Winchester; for boiling choler chokes

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The hollow passage of my poisond voice,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: By sight of these our baleful enemies.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: CARDINAL

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Charles, and the rest, it is enacted thus:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: That, in regard King Henry gives consent,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Of mere compassion and of lenity,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: To ease your country of distressful war,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And suffer you to breathe in fruitful peace,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: You shall become true liegemen to his crown:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And Charles, upon condition thou wilt swear

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: To pay him tribute, submit thyself,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Thou shalt be placed as viceroy under him,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And still enjoy thy regal dignity.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Must he be then as shadow of himself?

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Adorn his temples with a coronet,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: And yet, in substance and authority,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Retain but privilege of a private man?

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: This proffer is absurd and reasonless.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Tis known already that I am possessd

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: With more than half the Gallian territories,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And therein reverenced for their lawful king:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Shall I, for lucre of the rest unvanquishd,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Detract so much from that prerogative,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: As to be calld but viceroy of the whole?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: No, lord ambassador, Ill rather keep

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: That which I have than, coveting for more,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Be cast from possibility of all.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Insulting Charles! hast thou by secret means

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Used intercession to obtain a league,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And, now the matter grows to compromise,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Standst thou aloof upon comparison?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Either accept the title thou usurpst,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Of benefit proceeding from our king

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And not of any challenge of desert,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Or we will plague thee with incessant wars.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: My lord, you do not well in obstinacy

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: To cavil in the course of this contract:

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: If once it be neglected, ten to one

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: We shall not find like opportunity.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: To say the truth, it is your policy

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: To save your subjects from such massacre

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: And ruthless slaughters as are daily seen

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: By our proceeding in hostility;

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: And therefore take this compact of a truce,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Although you break it when your pleasure serves.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: How sayst thou, Charles? shall our condition stand?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: It shall;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Only reserved, you claim no interest

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: In any of our towns of garrison.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Then swear allegiance to his majesty,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: As thou art knight, never to disobey

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Nor be rebellious to the crown of England,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thou, nor thy nobles, to the crown of England.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: So, now dismiss your army when ye please:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Hang up your ensign, let your drums be still,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For here we entertain a solemn peace.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: YORK
text_entry: SCENE V. London. The palace.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter SUFFOLK in conference with KING HENRY VI, GLOUCESTER and EXETER

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Your wondrous rare description, noble earl,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Of beauteous Margaret hath astonishd me:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Her virtues graced with external gifts

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Do breed loves settled passions in my heart:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And like as rigor of tempestuous gusts

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Provokes the mightiest hulk against the tide,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So am I driven by breath of her renown

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Either to suffer shipwreck or arrive

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Where I may have fruition of her love.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Tush, my good lord, this superficial tale

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Is but a preface of her worthy praise;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: The chief perfections of that lovely dame

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Had I sufficient skill to utter them,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Would make a volume of enticing lines,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Able to ravish any dull conceit:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And, which is more, she is not so divine,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: So full-replete with choice of all delights,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: But with as humble lowliness of mind

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: She is content to be at your command;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Command, I mean, of virtuous chaste intents,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: To love and honour Henry as her lord.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And otherwise will Henry neer presume.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Therefore, my lord protector, give consent

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That Margaret may be Englands royal queen.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So should I give consent to flatter sin.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: You know, my lord, your highness is betrothd

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Unto another lady of esteem:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: How shall we then dispense with that contract,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And not deface your honour with reproach?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: As doth a ruler with unlawful oaths;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Or one that, at a triumph having vowd

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: To try his strength, forsaketh yet the lists

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: By reason of his adversarys odds:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: A poor earls daughter is unequal odds,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And therefore may be broke without offence.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
