speaker: Captain
text_entry: Be not so rash; take ransom, let him live.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Look on my George; I am a gentleman:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Rate me at what thou wilt, thou shalt be paid.

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: And so am I; my name is Walter Whitmore.

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: How now! why startst thou? what, doth

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: death affright?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Thy name affrights me, in whose sound is death.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: A cunning man did calculate my birth

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And told me that by water I should die:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Yet let not this make thee be bloody-minded;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Thy name is Gaultier, being rightly sounded.

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: Gaultier or Walter, which it is, I care not:

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: Never yet did base dishonour blur our name,

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: But with our sword we wiped away the blot;

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: Therefore, when merchant-like I sell revenge,

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: Broke be my sword, my arms torn and defaced,

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: And I proclaimd a coward through the world!

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Stay, Whitmore; for thy prisoner is a prince,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: The Duke of Suffolk, William de la Pole.

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: The Duke of Suffolk muffled up in rags!

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Ay, but these rags are no part of the duke:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Jove sometimes went disguised, and why not I?

speaker: Captain
text_entry: But Jove was never slain, as thou shalt be.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Obscure and lowly swain, King Henrys blood,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: The honourable blood of Lancaster,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Must not be shed by such a jaded groom.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Hast thou not kissd thy hand and held my stirrup?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Bare-headed plodded by my foot-cloth mule

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And thought thee happy when I shook my head?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: How often hast thou waited at my cup,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Fed from my trencher, kneeld down at the board.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: When I have feasted with Queen Margaret?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Remember it and let it make thee crest-falln,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Ay, and allay this thy abortive pride;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: How in our voiding lobby hast thou stood

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And duly waited for my coming forth?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: This hand of mine hath writ in thy behalf,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And therefore shall it charm thy riotous tongue.

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: Speak, captain, shall I stab the forlorn swain?

speaker: Captain
text_entry: First let my words stab him, as he hath me.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Base slave, thy words are blunt and so art thou.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Convey him hence and on our longboats side

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Strike off his head.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Thou darest not, for thy own.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Yes, Pole.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Pole!

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Pool! Sir Pool! lord!

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Ay, kennel, puddle, sink; whose filth and dirt

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Troubles the silver spring where England drinks.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Now will I dam up this thy yawning mouth

speaker: Captain
text_entry: For swallowing the treasure of the realm:

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Thy lips that kissd the queen shall sweep the ground;

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And thou that smiledst at good Duke Humphreys death,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Against the senseless winds shalt grin in vain,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Who in contempt shall hiss at thee again:

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And wedded be thou to the hags of hell,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: For daring to affy a mighty lord

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Unto the daughter of a worthless king,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Having neither subject, wealth, nor diadem.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: By devilish policy art thou grown great,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And, like ambitious Sylla, overgorged

speaker: Captain
text_entry: With gobbets of thy mothers bleeding heart.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: By thee Anjou and Maine were sold to France,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: The false revolting Normans thorough thee

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Disdain to call us lord, and Picardy

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Hath slain their governors, surprised our forts,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And sent the ragged soldiers wounded home.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: The princely Warwick, and the Nevils all,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Whose dreadful swords were never drawn in vain,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: As hating thee, are rising up in arms:

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And now the house of York, thrust from the crown

speaker: Captain
text_entry: By shameful murder of a guiltless king

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And lofty proud encroaching tyranny,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Burns with revenging fire; whose hopeful colours

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Advance our half-faced sun, striving to shine,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Under the which is writ Invitis nubibus.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: The commons here in Kent are up in arms:

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And, to conclude, reproach and beggary

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Is crept into the palace of our king.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And all by thee. Away! convey him hence.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: O that I were a god, to shoot forth thunder

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Upon these paltry, servile, abject drudges!

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Small things make base men proud: this villain here,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Being captain of a pinnace, threatens more

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Than Bargulus the strong Illyrian pirate.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Drones suck not eagles blood but rob beehives:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: It is impossible that I should die

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: By such a lowly vassal as thyself.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Thy words move rage and not remorse in me:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: I go of message from the queen to France;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: I charge thee waft me safely cross the Channel.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Walter,--

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: Come, Suffolk, I must waft thee to thy death.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Gelidus timor occupat artus it is thee I fear.

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: Thou shalt have cause to fear before I leave thee.

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: What, are ye daunted now? now will ye stoop?

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: My gracious lord, entreat him, speak him fair.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Suffolks imperial tongue is stern and rough,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Used to command, untaught to plead for favour.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Far be it we should honour such as these

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: With humble suit: no, rather let my head

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Stoop to the block than these knees bow to any

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Save to the God of heaven and to my king;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And sooner dance upon a bloody pole

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Than stand uncoverd to the vulgar groom.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: True nobility is exempt from fear:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: More can I bear than you dare execute.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Hale him away, and let him talk no more.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Come, soldiers, show what cruelty ye can,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: That this my death may never be forgot!

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Great men oft die by vile bezonians:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: A Roman sworder and banditto slave

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Murderd sweet Tully; Brutus bastard hand

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Stabbd Julius Caesar; savage islanders

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Pompey the Great; and Suffolk dies by pirates.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Exeunt Whitmore and others with Suffolk

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And as for these whose ransom we have set,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: It is our pleasure one of them depart;

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Therefore come you with us and let him go.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Exeunt all but the First Gentleman

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Re-enter WHITMORE with SUFFOLKs body

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: There let his head and lifeless body lie,

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: Until the queen his mistress bury it.

speaker: WHITMORE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: O barbarous and bloody spectacle!

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: His body will I bear unto the king:

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: If he revenge it not, yet will his friends;

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: So will the queen, that living held him dear.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Exit with the body

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: SCENE II. Blackheath.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Enter GEORGE BEVIS and JOHN HOLLAND

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: Come, and get thee a sword, though made of a lath;

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: they have been up these two days.

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: They have the more need to sleep now, then.

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: I tell thee, Jack Cade the clothier means to dress

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: the commonwealth, and turn it, and set a new nap upon it.

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: So he had need, for tis threadbare. Well, I say it

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: was never merry world in England since gentlemen came up.

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: O miserable age! virtue is not regarded in handicrafts-men.

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: The nobility think scorn to go in leather aprons.

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: Nay, more, the kings council are no good workmen.

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: True; and yet it is said, labour in thy vocation;

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: which is as much to say as, let the magistrates be

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: labouring men; and therefore should we be

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: magistrates.

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: Thou hast hit it; for theres no better sign of a

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: brave mind than a hard hand.

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: I see them! I see them! theres Bests son, the

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: tanner of Wingham,--

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: He shall have the skin of our enemies, to make

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: dogs-leather of.

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: And Dick the Butcher,--

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: Then is sin struck down like an ox, and iniquitys

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: throat cut like a calf.

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: And Smith the weaver,--

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: Argo, their thread of life is spun.

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: Come, come, lets fall in with them.

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: Drum. Enter CADE, DICK the Butcher, SMITH the Weaver, and a Sawyer, with infinite numbers

speaker: CADE
text_entry: We John Cade, so termed of our supposed father,--

speaker: DICK
text_entry: [Aside]  Or rather, of stealing a cade of herrings.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: For our enemies shall fall before us, inspired with

speaker: CADE
text_entry: the spirit of putting down kings and princes,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: --Command silence.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: Silence!

speaker: CADE
text_entry: My father was a Mortimer,--

speaker: DICK
text_entry: [Aside]  He was an honest man, and a good

speaker: DICK
text_entry: bricklayer.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: My mother a Plantagenet,--

speaker: DICK
text_entry: [Aside]  I knew her well; she was a midwife.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: My wife descended of the Lacies,--

speaker: DICK
text_entry: [Aside]  She was, indeed, a pedlers daughter, and

speaker: DICK
text_entry: sold many laces.

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: [Aside]  But now of late, notable to travel with her

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: furred pack, she washes bucks here at home.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Therefore am I of an honourable house.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: [Aside]  Ay, by my faith, the field is honourable;

speaker: DICK
text_entry: and there was he borne, under a hedge, for his

speaker: DICK
text_entry: father had never a house but the cage.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Valiant I am.

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: [Aside]  A must needs; for beggary is valiant.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: I am able to endure much.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: [Aside]  No question of that; for I have seen him

speaker: DICK
text_entry: whipped three market-days together.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: I fear neither sword nor fire.

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: [Aside]  He need not fear the sword; for his coat is of proof.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: [Aside]  But methinks he should stand in fear of

speaker: DICK
text_entry: fire, being burnt i the hand for stealing of sheep.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Be brave, then; for your captain is brave, and vows

speaker: CADE
text_entry: reformation. There shall be in England seven

speaker: CADE
text_entry: halfpenny loaves sold for a penny: the three-hooped

speaker: CADE
text_entry: pot; shall have ten hoops and I will make it felony

speaker: CADE
text_entry: to drink small beer: all the realm shall be in

speaker: CADE
text_entry: common; and in Cheapside shall my palfrey go to

speaker: CADE
text_entry: grass: and when I am king, as king I will be,--

speaker: ALL
text_entry: God save your majesty!

speaker: CADE
text_entry: I thank you, good people: there shall be no money;

speaker: CADE
text_entry: all shall eat and drink on my score; and I will

speaker: CADE
text_entry: apparel them all in one livery, that they may agree

speaker: CADE
text_entry: like brothers and worship me their lord.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: The first thing we do, lets kill all the lawyers.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Nay, that I mean to do. Is not this a lamentable

speaker: CADE
text_entry: thing, that of the skin of an innocent lamb should

speaker: CADE
text_entry: be made parchment? that parchment, being scribbled

speaker: CADE
text_entry: oer, should undo a man? Some say the bee stings:

speaker: CADE
text_entry: but I say, tis the bees wax; for I did but seal

speaker: CADE
text_entry: once to a thing, and I was never mine own man

speaker: CADE
text_entry: since. How now! whos there?

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Enter some, bringing forward the Clerk of Chatham

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: The clerk of Chatham: he can write and read and

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: cast accompt.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: O monstrous!

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: We took him setting of boys copies.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Heres a villain!

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: Has a book in his pocket with red letters int.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Nay, then, he is a conjurer.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: Nay, he can make obligations, and write court-hand.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: I am sorry fort: the man is a proper man, of mine

speaker: CADE
text_entry: honour; unless I find him guilty, he shall not die.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Come hither, sirrah, I must examine thee: what is thy name?

speaker: Clerk
text_entry: Emmanuel.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: They use to write it on the top of letters: twill

speaker: DICK
text_entry: go hard with you.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Let me alone. Dost thou use to write thy name? or

speaker: CADE
text_entry: hast thou a mark to thyself, like an honest

speaker: CADE
text_entry: plain-dealing man?

speaker: CLERK
text_entry: Sir, I thank God, I have been so well brought up

speaker: CLERK
text_entry: that I can write my name.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: He hath confessed: away with him! hes a villain

speaker: ALL
text_entry: and a traitor.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Away with him, I say! hang him with his pen and

speaker: CADE
text_entry: ink-horn about his neck.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Exit one with the Clerk

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Enter MICHAEL

speaker: MICHAEL
text_entry: Wheres our general?

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Here I am, thou particular fellow.

speaker: MICHAEL
text_entry: Fly, fly, fly! Sir Humphrey Stafford and his

speaker: MICHAEL
text_entry: brother are hard by, with the kings forces.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Stand, villain, stand, or Ill fell thee down. He

speaker: CADE
text_entry: shall be encountered with a man as good as himself:

speaker: CADE
text_entry: he is but a knight, is a?

speaker: MICHAEL
text_entry: No.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: To equal him, I will make myself a knight presently.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Kneels

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Rise up Sir John Mortimer.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Rises

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Now have at him!

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Enter SIR HUMPHREY and WILLIAM STAFFORD, with drum and soldiers

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: Rebellious hinds, the filth and scum of Kent,

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: Markd for the gallows, lay your weapons down;

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: Home to your cottages, forsake this groom:

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: The king is merciful, if you revolt.

speaker: WILLIAM STAFFORD
text_entry: But angry, wrathful, and inclined to blood,

speaker: WILLIAM STAFFORD
text_entry: If you go forward; therefore yield, or die.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: As for these silken-coated slaves, I pass not:

speaker: CADE
text_entry: It is to you, good people, that I speak,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Over whom, in time to come, I hope to reign;

speaker: CADE
text_entry: For I am rightful heir unto the crown.

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: Villain, thy father was a plasterer;

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: And thou thyself a shearman, art thou not?

speaker: CADE
text_entry: And Adam was a gardener.

speaker: WILLIAM STAFFORD
text_entry: And what of that?

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Marry, this: Edmund Mortimer, Earl of March.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Married the Duke of Clarence daughter, did he not?

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: Ay, sir.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: By her he had two children at one birth.

speaker: WILLIAM STAFFORD
text_entry: Thats false.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Ay, theres the question; but I say, tis true:

speaker: CADE
text_entry: The elder of them, being put to nurse,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Was by a beggar-woman stolen away;

speaker: CADE
text_entry: And, ignorant of his birth and parentage,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Became a bricklayer when he came to age:

speaker: CADE
text_entry: His son am I; deny it, if you can.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: Nay, tis too true; therefore he shall be king.

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: Sir, he made a chimney in my fathers house, and

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: the bricks are alive at this day to testify it;

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: therefore deny it not.

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: And will you credit this base drudges words,

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: That speaks he knows not what?

speaker: ALL
text_entry: Ay, marry, will we; therefore get ye gone.

speaker: WILLIAM STAFFORD
text_entry: Jack Cade, the Duke of York hath taught you this.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: [Aside]  He lies, for I invented it myself.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Go to, sirrah, tell the king from me, that, for his

speaker: CADE
text_entry: fathers sake, Henry the Fifth, in whose time boys

speaker: CADE
text_entry: went to span-counter for French crowns, I am content

speaker: CADE
text_entry: he shall reign; but Ill be protector over him.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: And furthermore, well have the Lord Says head for

speaker: DICK
text_entry: selling the dukedom of Maine.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: And good reason; for thereby is England mained, and

speaker: CADE
text_entry: fain to go with a staff, but that my puissance holds

speaker: CADE
text_entry: it up. Fellow kings, I tell you that that Lord Say

speaker: CADE
text_entry: hath gelded the commonwealth, and made it an eunuch:

speaker: CADE
text_entry: and more than that, he can speak French; and

speaker: CADE
text_entry: therefore he is a traitor.

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: O gross and miserable ignorance!

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Nay, answer, if you can: the Frenchmen are our

speaker: CADE
text_entry: enemies; go to, then, I ask but this: can he that

speaker: CADE
text_entry: speaks with the tongue of an enemy be a good

speaker: CADE
text_entry: counsellor, or no?

speaker: ALL
text_entry: No, no; and therefore well have his head.

speaker: WILLIAM STAFFORD
text_entry: Well, seeing gentle words will not prevail,

speaker: WILLIAM STAFFORD
text_entry: Assail them with the army of the king.

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: Herald, away; and throughout every town

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: Proclaim them traitors that are up with Cade;

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: That those which fly before the battle ends

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: May, even in their wives and childrens sight,

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: Be hangd up for example at their doors:

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: And you that be the kings friends, follow me.

speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
text_entry: Exeunt WILLIAM STAFFORD and SIR HUMPHREY, and soldiers

speaker: CADE
text_entry: And you that love the commons, follow me.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Now show yourselves men; tis for liberty.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: We will not leave one lord, one gentleman:

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Spare none but such as go in clouted shoon;

speaker: CADE
text_entry: For they are thrifty honest men, and such

speaker: CADE
text_entry: As would, but that they dare not, take our parts.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: They are all in order and march toward us.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: But then are we in order when we are most

speaker: CADE
text_entry: out of order. Come, march forward.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CADE
text_entry: SCENE III. Another part of Blackheath.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Alarums to the fight, wherein SIR HUMPHREY and WILLIAM STAFFORD are slain. Enter CADE and the rest

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Wheres Dick, the butcher of Ashford?

speaker: DICK
text_entry: Here, sir.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: They fell before thee like sheep and oxen, and thou

speaker: CADE
text_entry: behavedst thyself as if thou hadst been in thine own

speaker: CADE
text_entry: slaughter-house: therefore thus will I reward thee,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: the Lent shall be as long again as it is; and thou

speaker: CADE
text_entry: shalt have a licence to kill for a hundred lacking

speaker: CADE
text_entry: one.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: I desire no more.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: And, to speak truth, thou deservest no less. This

speaker: CADE
text_entry: monument of the victory will I bear;

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Putting on SIR HUMPHREYS brigandine

speaker: CADE
text_entry: and the bodies shall be dragged at my horse heels

speaker: CADE
text_entry: till I do come to London, where we will have the

speaker: CADE
text_entry: mayors sword borne before us.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: If we mean to thrive and do good, break open the

speaker: DICK
text_entry: gaols and let out the prisoners.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Fear not that, I warrant thee. Come, lets march

speaker: CADE
text_entry: towards London.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CADE
text_entry: SCENE IV. London. The palace.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Enter KING HENRY VI with a supplication, and the QUEEN with SUFFOLKS head, BUCKINGHAM and Lord SAY

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Oft have I heard that grief softens the mind,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And makes it fearful and degenerate;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Think therefore on revenge and cease to weep.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But who can cease to weep and look on this?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Here may his head lie on my throbbing breast:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But wheres the body that I should embrace?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: What answer makes your grace to the rebels

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: supplication?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ill send some holy bishop to entreat;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For God forbid so many simple souls

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Should perish by the sword! And I myself,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Rather than bloody war shall cut them short,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Will parley with Jack Cade their general:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But stay, Ill read it over once again.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ah, barbarous villains! hath this lovely face

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ruled, like a wandering planet, over me,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And could it not enforce them to relent,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That were unworthy to behold the same?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Lord Say, Jack Cade hath sworn to have thy head.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Ay, but I hope your highness shall have his.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How now, madam!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Still lamenting and mourning for Suffolks death?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I fear me, love, if that I had been dead,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thou wouldst not have mournd so much for me.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: No, my love, I should not mourn, but die for thee.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How now! what news? why comest thou in such haste?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The rebels are in Southwark; fly, my lord!

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Jack Cade proclaims himself Lord Mortimer,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Descended from the Duke of Clarence house,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And calls your grace usurper openly

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And vows to crown himself in Westminster.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: His army is a ragged multitude

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Of hinds and peasants, rude and merciless:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Sir Humphrey Stafford and h is brothers death

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Hath given them heart and courage to proceed:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: All scholars, lawyers, courtiers, gentlemen,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: They call false caterpillars, and intend their death.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O graceless men! they know not what they do.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: My gracious lord, return to Killingworth,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Until a power be raised to put them down.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ah, were the Duke of Suffolk now alive,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: These Kentish rebels would be soon appeased!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Lord Say, the traitors hate thee;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Therefore away with us to Killingworth.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: So might your graces person be in danger.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: The sight of me is odious in their eyes;

speaker: SAY
text_entry: And therefore in this city will I stay

speaker: SAY
text_entry: And live alone as secret as I may.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Enter another Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Jack Cade hath gotten London bridge:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The citizens fly and forsake their houses:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The rascal people, thirsting after prey,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Join with the traitor, and they jointly swear

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: To spoil the city and your royal court.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Then linger not, my lord, away, take horse.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Come, Margaret; God, our hope, will succor us.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: My hope is gone, now Suffolk is deceased.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Farewell, my lord: trust not the Kentish rebels.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Trust nobody, for fear you be betrayd.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: The trust I have is in mine innocence,

speaker: SAY
text_entry: And therefore am I bold and resolute.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: SAY
text_entry: SCENE V. London. The Tower.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Enter SCALES upon the Tower, walking. Then enter two or three Citizens below

speaker: SCALES
text_entry: How now! is Jack Cade slain?

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: No, my lord, nor likely to be slain; for they have

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: won the bridge, killing all those that withstand

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: them: the lord mayor craves aid of your honour from

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: the Tower, to defend the city from the rebels.

speaker: SCALES
text_entry: Such aid as I can spare you shall command;

speaker: SCALES
text_entry: But I am troubled here with them myself;

speaker: SCALES
text_entry: The rebels have assayd to win the Tower.

speaker: SCALES
text_entry: But get you to Smithfield, and gather head,

speaker: SCALES
text_entry: And thither I will send you Matthew Goffe;

speaker: SCALES
text_entry: Fight for your king, your country and your lives;

speaker: SCALES
text_entry: And so, farewell, for I must hence again.

speaker: SCALES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: SCALES
text_entry: SCENE VI. London. Cannon Street.

speaker: SCALES
text_entry: Enter CADE and the rest, and strikes his staff on London-stone

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Now is Mortimer lord of this city. And here, sitting

speaker: CADE
text_entry: upon London-stone, I charge and command that, of the

speaker: CADE
text_entry: citys cost, the pissing-conduit run nothing but

speaker: CADE
text_entry: claret wine this first year of our reign. And now

speaker: CADE
text_entry: henceforward it shall be treason for any that calls

speaker: CADE
text_entry: me other than Lord Mortimer.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Enter a Soldier, running

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Jack Cade! Jack Cade!

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Knock him down there.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: They kill him

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: If this fellow be wise, hell never call ye Jack

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: Cade more: I think he hath a very fair warning.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: My lord, theres an army gathered together in

speaker: DICK
text_entry: Smithfield.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Come, then, lets go fight with them; but first, go

speaker: CADE
text_entry: and set London bridge on fire; and, if you can, burn

speaker: CADE
text_entry: down the Tower too. Come, lets away.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CADE
text_entry: SCENE VII. London. Smithfield.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Alarums. MATTHEW GOFFE is slain, and all the rest. Then enter CADE, with his company.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: So, sirs: now go some and pull down the Savoy;

speaker: CADE
text_entry: others to the inns of court; down with them all.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: I have a suit unto your lordship.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Be it a lordship, thou shalt have it for that word.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: Only that the laws of England may come out of your mouth.

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: [Aside]  Mass, twill be sore law, then; for he was

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: thrust in the mouth with a spear, and tis not whole

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: yet.

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: [Aside]  Nay, John, it will be stinking law for his

speaker: SMITH
text_entry: breath stinks with eating toasted cheese.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: I have thought upon it, it shall be so. Away, burn

speaker: CADE
text_entry: all the records of the realm: my mouth shall be

speaker: CADE
text_entry: the parliament of England.

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: [Aside]  Then we are like to have biting statutes,

speaker: HOLLAND
text_entry: unless his teeth be pulled out.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: And henceforward all things shall be in common.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My lord, a prize, a prize! heres the Lord Say,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: which sold the towns in France; he that made us pay

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: one and twenty fifteens, and one shilling to the

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: pound, the last subsidy.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Enter BEVIS, with Lord SAY

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Well, he shall be beheaded for it ten times. Ah,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: thou say, thou serge, nay, thou buckram lord! now

speaker: CADE
text_entry: art thou within point-blank of our jurisdiction

speaker: CADE
text_entry: regal. What canst thou answer to my majesty for

speaker: CADE
text_entry: giving up of Normandy unto Mounsieur Basimecu, the

speaker: CADE
text_entry: dauphin of France? Be it known unto thee by these

speaker: CADE
text_entry: presence, even the presence of Lord Mortimer, that I

speaker: CADE
text_entry: am the besom that must sweep the court clean of such

speaker: CADE
text_entry: filth as thou art. Thou hast most traitorously

speaker: CADE
text_entry: corrupted the youth of the realm in erecting a

speaker: CADE
text_entry: grammar school; and whereas, before, our forefathers

speaker: CADE
text_entry: had no other books but the score and the tally, thou

speaker: CADE
text_entry: hast caused printing to be used, and, contrary to

speaker: CADE
text_entry: the king, his crown and dignity, thou hast built a

speaker: CADE
text_entry: paper-mill. It will be proved to thy face that thou

speaker: CADE
text_entry: hast men about thee that usually talk of a noun and

speaker: CADE
text_entry: a verb, and such abominable words as no Christian

speaker: CADE
text_entry: ear can endure to hear. Thou hast appointed

speaker: CADE
text_entry: justices of peace, to call poor men before them

speaker: CADE
text_entry: about matters they were not able to answer.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Moreover, thou hast put them in prison; and because

speaker: CADE
text_entry: they could not read, thou hast hanged them; when,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: indeed, only for that cause they have been most

speaker: CADE
text_entry: worthy to live. Thou dost ride in a foot-cloth, dost thou not?

speaker: SAY
text_entry: What of that?

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Marry, thou oughtest not to let thy horse wear a

speaker: CADE
text_entry: cloak, when honester men than thou go in their hose

speaker: CADE
text_entry: and doublets.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: And work in their shirt too; as myself, for example,

speaker: DICK
text_entry: that am a butcher.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: You men of Kent,--

speaker: DICK
text_entry: What say you of Kent?

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Nothing but this; tis bona terra, mala gens.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Away with him, away with him! he speaks Latin.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Hear me but speak, and bear me where you will.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Kent, in the Commentaries Caesar writ,

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Is termd the civilst place of this isle:

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Sweet is the country, because full of riches;

speaker: SAY
text_entry: The people liberal, valiant, active, wealthy;

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Which makes me hope you are not void of pity.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: I sold not Maine, I lost not Normandy,

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Yet, to recover them, would lose my life.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Justice with favour have I always done;

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Prayers and tears have moved me, gifts could never.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: When have I aught exacted at your hands,

speaker: SAY
text_entry: But to maintain the king, the realm and you?

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Large gifts have I bestowd on learned clerks,

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Because my book preferrd me to the king,

speaker: SAY
text_entry: And seeing ignorance is the curse of God,

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Knowledge the wing wherewith we fly to heaven,

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Unless you be possessd with devilish spirits,

speaker: SAY
text_entry: You cannot but forbear to murder me:

speaker: SAY
text_entry: This tongue hath parleyd unto foreign kings

speaker: SAY
text_entry: For your behoof,--

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Tut, when struckst thou one blow in the field?

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Great men have reaching hands: oft have I struck

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Those that I never saw and struck them dead.

speaker: BEVIS
text_entry: O monstrous coward! what, to come behind folks?

speaker: SAY
text_entry: These cheeks are pale for watching for your good.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Give him a box o the ear and that will make em red again.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Long sitting to determine poor mens causes

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Hath made me full of sickness and diseases.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Ye shall have a hempen caudle, then, and the help of hatchet.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: Why dost thou quiver, man?

speaker: SAY
text_entry: The palsy, and not fear, provokes me.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Nay, he nods at us, as who should say, Ill be even

speaker: CADE
text_entry: with you: Ill see if his head will stand steadier

speaker: CADE
text_entry: on a pole, or no. Take him away, and behead him.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Tell me wherein have I offended most?

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Have I affected wealth or honour? speak.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Are my chests filld up with extorted gold?

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Is my apparel sumptuous to behold?

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Whom have I injured, that ye seek my death?

speaker: SAY
text_entry: These hands are free from guiltless bloodshedding,

speaker: SAY
text_entry: This breast from harbouring foul deceitful thoughts.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: O, let me live!

speaker: CADE
text_entry: [Aside]  I feel remorse in myself with his words;

speaker: CADE
text_entry: but Ill bridle it: he shall die, an it be but for

speaker: CADE
text_entry: pleading so well for his life. Away with him! he

speaker: CADE
text_entry: has a familiar under his tongue; he speaks not o

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Gods name. Go, take him away, I say, and strike

speaker: CADE
text_entry: off his head presently; and then break into his

speaker: CADE
text_entry: son-in-laws house, Sir James Cromer, and strike off

speaker: CADE
text_entry: his head, and bring them both upon two poles hither.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: It shall be done.

speaker: SAY
text_entry: Ah, countrymen! if when you make your prayers,

speaker: SAY
text_entry: God should be so obdurate as yourselves,

speaker: SAY
text_entry: How would it fare with your departed souls?

speaker: SAY
text_entry: And therefore yet relent, and save my life.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Away with him! and do as I command ye.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Exeunt some with Lord SAY

speaker: CADE
text_entry: The proudest peer in the realm shall not wear a head

speaker: CADE
text_entry: on his shoulders, unless he pay me tribute; there

speaker: CADE
text_entry: shall not a maid be married, but she shall pay to me

speaker: CADE
text_entry: her maidenhead ere they have it: men shall hold of

speaker: CADE
text_entry: me in capite; and we charge and command that their

speaker: CADE
text_entry: wives be as free as heart can wish or tongue can tell.

speaker: DICK
text_entry: My lord, when shall we go to Cheapside and take up

speaker: DICK
text_entry: commodities upon our bills?

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Marry, presently.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: O, brave!

speaker: ALL
text_entry: Re-enter one with the heads

speaker: CADE
text_entry: But is not this braver? Let them kiss one another,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: for they loved well when they were alive. Now part

speaker: CADE
text_entry: them again, lest they consult about the giving up of

speaker: CADE
text_entry: some more towns in France. Soldiers, defer the

speaker: CADE
text_entry: spoil of the city until night: for with these borne

speaker: CADE
text_entry: before us, instead of maces, will we ride through

speaker: CADE
text_entry: the streets, and at every corner have them kiss. Away!

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CADE
text_entry: SCENE VIII. Southwark.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Alarum and retreat. Enter CADE and all his rabblement

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Up Fish Street! down Saint Magnus Corner! Kill

speaker: CADE
text_entry: and knock down! throw them into Thames!

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Sound a parley

speaker: CADE
text_entry: What noise is this I hear? Dare any be so bold to

speaker: CADE
text_entry: sound retreat or parley, when I command them kill?

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Enter BUCKINGHAM and CLIFFORD, attended

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Ay, here they be that dare and will disturb thee:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Know, Cade, we come ambassadors from the king

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Unto the commons whom thou hast misled;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And here pronounce free pardon to them all

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: That will forsake thee and go home in peace.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: What say ye, countrymen? will ye relent,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And yield to mercy whilst tis offerd you;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Or let a rebel lead you to your deaths?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Who loves the king and will embrace his pardon,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Fling up his cap, and say God save his majesty!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Who hateth him and honours not his father,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Henry the Fifth, that made all France to quake,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Shake he his weapon at us and pass by.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: God save the king! God save the king!

speaker: CADE
text_entry: What, Buckingham and Clifford, are ye so brave? And

speaker: CADE
text_entry: you, base peasants, do ye believe him? will you

speaker: CADE
text_entry: needs be hanged with your pardons about your necks?

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Hath my sword therefore broke through London gates,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: that you should leave me at the White Hart in

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Southwark? I thought ye would never have given out

speaker: CADE
text_entry: these arms till you had recovered your ancient

speaker: CADE
text_entry: freedom: but you are all recreants and dastards,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: and delight to live in slavery to the nobility. Let

speaker: CADE
text_entry: them break your backs with burthens, take your

speaker: CADE
text_entry: houses over your heads, ravish your wives and

speaker: CADE
text_entry: daughters before your faces: for me, I will make

speaker: CADE
text_entry: shift for one; and so, Gods curse light upon you

speaker: CADE
text_entry: all!

speaker: ALL
text_entry: Well follow Cade, well follow Cade!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Is Cade the son of Henry the Fifth,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: That thus you do exclaim youll go with him?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Will he conduct you through the heart of France,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And make the meanest of you earls and dukes?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Alas, he hath no home, no place to fly to;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Nor knows he how to live but by the spoil,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Unless by robbing of your friends and us.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Weret not a shame, that whilst you live at jar,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The fearful French, whom you late vanquished,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Should make a start oer seas and vanquish you?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Methinks already in this civil broil

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I see them lording it in London streets,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Crying Villiago! unto all they meet.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Better ten thousand base-born Cades miscarry

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Than you should stoop unto a Frenchmans mercy.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: To France, to France, and get what you have lost;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Spare England, for it is your native coast;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Henry hath money, you are strong and manly;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: God on our side, doubt not of victory.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: A Clifford! a Clifford! well follow the king and Clifford.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Was ever feather so lightly blown to and fro as this

speaker: CADE
text_entry: multitude? The name of Henry the Fifth hales them

speaker: CADE
text_entry: to an hundred mischiefs, and makes them leave me

speaker: CADE
text_entry: desolate. I see them lay their heads together to

speaker: CADE
text_entry: surprise me. My sword make way for me, for here is

speaker: CADE
text_entry: no staying. In despite of the devils and hell, have

speaker: CADE
text_entry: through the very middest of you? and heavens and

speaker: CADE
text_entry: honour be witness, that no want of resolution in me.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: but only my followers base and ignominious

speaker: CADE
text_entry: treasons, makes me betake me to my heels.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: What, is he fled? Go some, and follow him;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And he that brings his head unto the king

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Shall have a thousand crowns for his reward.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Exeunt some of them

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Follow me, soldiers: well devise a mean

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To reconcile you all unto the king.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: SCENE IX. Kenilworth Castle.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Sound Trumpets. Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET, and SOMERSET, on the terrace

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Was ever king that joyd an earthly throne,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And could command no more content than I?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: No sooner was I crept out of my cradle

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But I was made a king, at nine months old.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Was never subject longd to be a king

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: As I do long and wish to be a subject.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enter BUCKINGHAM and CLIFFORD

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Health and glad tidings to your majesty!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Why, Buckingham, is the traitor Cade surprised?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Or is he but retired to make him strong?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enter below, multitudes, with halters about their necks

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: He is fled, my lord, and all his powers do yield;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And humbly thus, with halters on their necks,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Expect your highness doom of life or death.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Then, heaven, set ope thy everlasting gates,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To entertain my vows of thanks and praise!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Soldiers, this day have you redeemed your lives,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And showd how well you love your prince and country:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Continue still in this so good a mind,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And Henry, though he be infortunate,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Assure yourselves, will never be unkind:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And so, with thanks and pardon to you all,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I do dismiss you to your several countries.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: God save the king! God save the king!

speaker: ALL
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Please it your grace to be advertised

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Duke of York is newly come from Ireland,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And with a puissant and a mighty power

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Of gallowglasses and stout kerns

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Is marching hitherward in proud array,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And still proclaimeth, as he comes along,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: His arms are only to remove from thee

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Duke of Somerset, whom he terms traitor.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thus stands my state, twixt Cade and York distressd.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Like to a ship that, having scaped a tempest,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Is straightway calmd and boarded with a pirate:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But now is Cade driven back, his men dispersed;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And now is York in arms to second him.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I pray thee, Buckingham, go and meet him,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And ask him whats the reason of these arms.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Tell him Ill send Duke Edmund to the Tower;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And, Somerset, well commit thee thither,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Until his army be dismissd from him.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: My lord,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Ill yield myself to prison willingly,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Or unto death, to do my country good.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: In any case, be not too rough in terms;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For he is fierce and cannot brook hard language.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I will, my lord; and doubt not so to deal

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: As all things shall redound unto your good.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Come, wife, lets in, and learn to govern better;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For yet may England curse my wretched reign.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: SCENE X. Kent. IDENs garden.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enter CADE

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Fie on ambition! fie on myself, that have a sword,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: and yet am ready to famish! These five days have I

speaker: CADE
text_entry: hid me in these woods and durst not peep out, for

speaker: CADE
text_entry: all the country is laid for me; but now am I so

speaker: CADE
text_entry: hungry that if I might have a lease of my life for a

speaker: CADE
text_entry: thousand years I could stay no longer. Wherefore,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: on a brick wall have I climbed into this garden, to

speaker: CADE
text_entry: see if I can eat grass, or pick a sallet another

speaker: CADE
text_entry: while, which is not amiss to cool a mans stomach

speaker: CADE
text_entry: this hot weather. And I think this word sallet

speaker: CADE
text_entry: was born to do me good: for many a time, but for a

speaker: CADE
text_entry: sallet, my brainpan had been cleft with a brown

speaker: CADE
text_entry: bill; and many a time, when I have been dry and

speaker: CADE
text_entry: bravely marching, it hath served me instead of a

speaker: CADE
text_entry: quart pot to drink in; and now the word sallet

speaker: CADE
text_entry: must serve me to feed on.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Enter IDEN

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Lord, who would live turmoiled in the court,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: And may enjoy such quiet walks as these?

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: This small inheritance my father left me

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Contenteth me, and worth a monarchy.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: I seek not to wax great by others waning,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Or gather wealth, I care not, with what envy:

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Sufficeth that I have maintains my state

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: And sends the poor well pleased from my gate.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Heres the lord of the soil come to seize me for a

speaker: CADE
text_entry: stray, for entering his fee-simple without leave.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Ah, villain, thou wilt betray me, and get a thousand

speaker: CADE
text_entry: crowns of the king carrying my head to him: but

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Ill make thee eat iron like an ostrich, and swallow

speaker: CADE
text_entry: my sword like a great pin, ere thou and I part.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Why, rude companion, whatsoeer thou be,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: I know thee not; why, then, should I betray thee?

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Ist not enough to break into my garden,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: And, like a thief, to come to rob my grounds,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Climbing my walls in spite of me the owner,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: But thou wilt brave me with these saucy terms?

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Brave thee! ay, by the best blood that ever was

speaker: CADE
text_entry: broached, and beard thee too. Look on me well: I

speaker: CADE
text_entry: have eat no meat these five days; yet, come thou and

speaker: CADE
text_entry: thy five men, and if I do not leave you all as dead

speaker: CADE
text_entry: as a doornail, I pray God I may never eat grass more.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Nay, it shall neer be said, while England stands,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: That Alexander Iden, an esquire of Kent,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Took odds to combat a poor famishd man.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Oppose thy steadfast-gazing eyes to mine,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: See if thou canst outface me with thy looks:

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Set limb to limb, and thou art far the lesser;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Thy hand is but a finger to my fist,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Thy leg a stick compared with this truncheon;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: My foot shall fight with all the strength thou hast;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: And if mine arm be heaved in the air,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Thy grave is diggd already in the earth.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: As for words, whose greatness answers words,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Let this my sword report what speech forbears.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: By my valour, the most complete champion that ever I

speaker: CADE
text_entry: heard! Steel, if thou turn the edge, or cut not out

speaker: CADE
text_entry: the burly-boned clown in chines of beef ere thou

speaker: CADE
text_entry: sleep in thy sheath, I beseech God on my knees thou

speaker: CADE
text_entry: mayst be turned to hobnails.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Here they fight. CADE falls

speaker: CADE
text_entry: O, I am slain! famine and no other hath slain me:

speaker: CADE
text_entry: let ten thousand devils come against me, and give me

speaker: CADE
text_entry: but the ten meals I have lost, and Ill defy them

speaker: CADE
text_entry: all. Wither, garden; and be henceforth a

speaker: CADE
text_entry: burying-place to all that do dwell in this house,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: because the unconquered soul of Cade is fled.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Ist Cade that I have slain, that monstrous traitor?

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Sword, I will hollow thee for this thy deed,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: And hang thee oer my tomb when I am dead:

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Neer shall this blood be wiped from thy point;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: But thou shalt wear it as a heralds coat,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: To emblaze the honour that thy master got.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Iden, farewell, and be proud of thy victory. Tell

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Kent from me, she hath lost her best man, and exhort

speaker: CADE
text_entry: all the world to be cowards; for I, that never

speaker: CADE
text_entry: feared any, am vanquished by famine, not by valour.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Dies

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: How much thou wrongst me, heaven be my judge.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Die, damned wretch, the curse of her that bare thee;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: And as I thrust thy body in with my sword,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: So wish I, I might thrust thy soul to hell.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Hence will I drag thee headlong by the heels

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Unto a dunghill which shall be thy grave,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: And there cut off thy most ungracious head;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Which I will bear in triumph to the king,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Leaving thy trunk for crows to feed upon.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Exit

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: SCENE I. Fields between Dartford and Blackheath.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Enter YORK, and his army of Irish, with drum and colours

speaker: YORK
text_entry: From Ireland thus comes York to claim his right,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And pluck the crown from feeble Henrys head:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Ring, bells, aloud; burn, bonfires, clear and bright,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To entertain great Englands lawful king.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Ah! sancta majestas, who would not buy thee dear?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Let them obey that know not how to rule;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: This hand was made to handle naught but gold.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I cannot give due action to my words,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Except a sword or sceptre balance it:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: A sceptre shall it have, have I a soul,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: On which Ill toss the flower-de-luce of France.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter BUCKINGHAM

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whom have we here? Buckingham, to disturb me?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The king hath sent him, sure: I must dissemble.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: York, if thou meanest well, I greet thee well.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Humphrey of Buckingham, I accept thy greeting.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Art thou a messenger, or come of pleasure?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: A messenger from Henry, our dread liege,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To know the reason of these arms in peace;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Or why thou, being a subject as I am,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Against thy oath and true allegiance sworn,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Should raise so great a power without his leave,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Or dare to bring thy force so near the court.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: [Aside]  Scarce can I speak, my choler is so great:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: O, I could hew up rocks and fight with flint,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I am so angry at these abject terms;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And now, like Ajax Telamonius,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: On sheep or oxen could I spend my fury.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I am far better born than is the king,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: More like a king, more kingly in my thoughts:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But I must make fair weather yet a while,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Till Henry be more weak and I more strong,--

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Buckingham, I prithee, pardon me,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That I have given no answer all this while;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: My mind was troubled with deep melancholy.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The cause why I have brought this army hither

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Is to remove proud Somerset from the king,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Seditious to his grace and to the state.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: That is too much presumption on thy part:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But if thy arms be to no other end,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The king hath yielded unto thy demand:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The Duke of Somerset is in the Tower.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Upon thine honour, is he prisoner?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Upon mine honour, he is prisoner.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Then, Buckingham, I do dismiss my powers.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Soldiers, I thank you all; disperse yourselves;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Meet me to-morrow in St. Georges field,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: You shall have pay and every thing you wish.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And let my sovereign, virtuous Henry,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Command my eldest son, nay, all my sons,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: As pledges of my fealty and love;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Ill send them all as willing as I live:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Lands, goods, horse, armour, any thing I have,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Is his to use, so Somerset may die.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: York, I commend this kind submission:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: We twain will go into his highness tent.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Enter KING HENRY VI and Attendants

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Buckingham, doth York intend no harm to us,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That thus he marcheth with thee arm in arm?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: In all submission and humility

speaker: YORK
text_entry: York doth present himself unto your highness.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Then what intends these forces thou dost bring?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To heave the traitor Somerset from hence,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And fight against that monstrous rebel Cade,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Who since I heard to be discomfited.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter IDEN, with CADES head

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: If one so rude and of so mean condition

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: May pass into the presence of a king,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Lo, I present your grace a traitors head,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: The head of Cade, whom I in combat slew.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The head of Cade! Great God, how just art Thou!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, let me view his visage, being dead,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That living wrought me such exceeding trouble.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Tell me, my friend, art thou the man that slew him?

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: I was, ant like your majesty.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How art thou calld? and what is thy degree?

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Alexander Iden, thats my name;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: A poor esquire of Kent, that loves his king.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: So please it you, my lord, twere not amiss

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: He were created knight for his good service.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Iden, kneel down.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: He kneels

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Rise up a knight.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: We give thee for reward a thousand marks,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And will that thou henceforth attend on us.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: May Iden live to merit such a bounty.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: And never live but true unto his liege!

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Rises

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Enter QUEEN MARGARET and SOMERSET

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: See, Buckingham, Somerset comes with the queen:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Go, bid her hide him quickly from the duke.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: For thousand Yorks he shall not hide his head,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But boldly stand and front him to his face.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: How now! is Somerset at liberty?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Then, York, unloose thy long-imprisond thoughts,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And let thy tongue be equal with thy heart.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Shall I endure the sight of Somerset?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: False king! why hast thou broken faith with me,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Knowing how hardly I can brook abuse?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: King did I call thee? no, thou art not king,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Not fit to govern and rule multitudes,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Which darest not, no, nor canst not rule a traitor.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That head of thine doth not become a crown;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thy hand is made to grasp a palmers staff,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And not to grace an awful princely sceptre.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That gold must round engirt these brows of mine,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whose smile and frown, like to Achilles spear,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Is able with the change to kill and cure.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Here is a hand to hold a sceptre up

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And with the same to act controlling laws.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Give place: by heaven, thou shalt rule no more

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Oer him whom heaven created for thy ruler.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: O monstrous traitor! I arrest thee, York,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Of capital treason gainst the king and crown;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Obey, audacious traitor; kneel for grace.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Wouldst have me kneel? first let me ask of these,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: If they can brook I bow a knee to man.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Sirrah, call in my sons to be my bail;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Exit Attendant

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I know, ere they will have me go to ward,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Theyll pawn their swords for my enfranchisement.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Call hither Clifford! bid him come amain,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To say if that the bastard boys of York

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Shall be the surety for their traitor father.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Exit BUCKINGHAM

speaker: YORK
text_entry: O blood-besotted Neapolitan,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Outcast of Naples, Englands bloody scourge!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The sons of York, thy betters in their birth,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Shall be their fathers bail; and bane to those

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That for my surety will refuse the boys!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter EDWARD and RICHARD

speaker: YORK
text_entry: See where they come: Ill warrant theyll

speaker: YORK
text_entry: make it good.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter CLIFFORD and YOUNG CLIFFORD

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And here comes Clifford to deny their bail.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Health and all happiness to my lord the king!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Kneels

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I thank thee, Clifford: say, what news with thee?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Nay, do not fright us with an angry look;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: We are thy sovereign, Clifford, kneel again;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For thy mistaking so, we pardon thee.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: This is my king, York, I do not mistake;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: But thou mistakest me much to think I do:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: To Bedlam with him! is the man grown mad?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ay, Clifford; a bedlam and ambitious humour

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Makes him oppose himself against his king.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: He is a traitor; let him to the Tower,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And chop away that factious pate of his.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: He is arrested, but will not obey;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: His sons, he says, shall give their words for him.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Will you not, sons?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Ay, noble father, if our words will serve.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And if words will not, then our weapons shall.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Why, what a brood of traitors have we here!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Look in a glass, and call thy image so:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I am thy king, and thou a false-heart traitor.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Call hither to the stake my two brave bears,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That with the very shaking of their chains

speaker: YORK
text_entry: They may astonish these fell-lurking curs:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Bid Salisbury and Warwick come to me.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter the WARWICK and SALISBURY

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Are these thy bears? well bait thy bears to death.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And manacle the bear-ward in their chains,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: If thou darest bring them to the baiting place.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Oft have I seen a hot oerweening cur

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Run back and bite, because he was withheld;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Who, being sufferd with the bears fell paw,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Hath clappd his tail between his legs and cried:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And such a piece of service will you do,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: If you oppose yourselves to match Lord Warwick.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Hence, heap of wrath, foul indigested lump,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: As crooked in thy manners as thy shape!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Nay, we shall heat you thoroughly anon.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Take heed, lest by your heat you burn yourselves.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Why, Warwick, hath thy knee forgot to bow?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Old Salisbury, shame to thy silver hair,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thou mad misleader of thy brain-sick son!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What, wilt thou on thy death-bed play the ruffian,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And seek for sorrow with thy spectacles?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, where is faith? O, where is loyalty?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If it be banishd from the frosty head,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Where shall it find a harbour in the earth?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Wilt thou go dig a grave to find out war,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And shame thine honourable age with blood?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Why art thou old, and wantst experience?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Or wherefore dost abuse it, if thou hast it?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For shame! in duty bend thy knee to me

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That bows unto the grave with mickle age.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: My lord, I have considerd with myself

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: The title of this most renowned duke;

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: And in my conscience do repute his grace

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: The rightful heir to Englands royal seat.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Hast thou not sworn allegiance unto me?

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: I have.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Canst thou dispense with heaven for such an oath?

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: It is great sin to swear unto a sin,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: But greater sin to keep a sinful oath.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Who can be bound by any solemn vow

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To do a murderous deed, to rob a man,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To force a spotless virgins chastity,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To reave the orphan of his patrimony,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To wring the widow from her customd right,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: And have no other reason for this wrong

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: But that he was bound by a solemn oath?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: A subtle traitor needs no sophister.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Call Buckingham, and bid him arm himself.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Call Buckingham, and all the friends thou hast,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I am resolved for death or dignity.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The first I warrant thee, if dreams prove true.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: You were best to go to bed and dream again,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To keep thee from the tempest of the field.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I am resolved to bear a greater storm

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Than any thou canst conjure up to-day;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And that Ill write upon thy burgonet,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Might I but know thee by thy household badge.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Now, by my fathers badge, old Nevils crest,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The rampant bear chaind to the ragged staff,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: This day Ill wear aloft my burgonet,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: As on a mountain top the cedar shows

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That keeps his leaves in spite of any storm,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Even to affright thee with the view thereof.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And from thy burgonet Ill rend thy bear

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And tread it under foot with all contempt,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Despite the bear-ward that protects the bear.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: And so to arms, victorious father,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: To quell the rebels and their complices.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Fie! charity, for shame! speak not in spite,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For you shall sup with Jesu Christ to-night.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Foul stigmatic, thats more than thou canst tell.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: If not in heaven, youll surely sup in hell.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Exeunt severally

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: SCENE II. Saint Albans.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Alarums to the battle. Enter WARWICK

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Clifford of Cumberland, tis Warwick calls:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And if thou dost not hide thee from the bear,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Now, when the angry trumpet sounds alarum

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And dead mens cries do fill the empty air,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Clifford, I say, come forth and fight with me:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Proud northern lord, Clifford of Cumberland,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Warwick is hoarse with calling thee to arms.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter YORK

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: How now, my noble lord? what, all afoot?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The deadly-handed Clifford slew my steed,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But match to match I have encounterd him

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And made a prey for carrion kites and crows

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Even of the bonny beast he loved so well.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter CLIFFORD

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Of one or both of us the time is come.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Hold, Warwick, seek thee out some other chase,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For I myself must hunt this deer to death.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then, nobly, York; tis for a crown thou fightst.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: As I intend, Clifford, to thrive to-day,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: It grieves my soul to leave thee unassaild.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: What seest thou in me, York? why dost thou pause?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: With thy brave bearing should I be in love,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But that thou art so fast mine enemy.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Nor should thy prowess want praise and esteem,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: But that tis shown ignobly and in treason.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: So let it help me now against thy sword

speaker: YORK
text_entry: As I in justice and true right express it.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: My soul and body on the action both!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: A dreadful lay! Address thee instantly.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: They fight, and CLIFFORD falls

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: La fin couronne les oeuvres.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Dies

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thus war hath given thee peace, for thou art still.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Peace with his soul, heaven, if it be thy will!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter YOUNG CLIFFORD

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Shame and confusion! all is on the rout;

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Fear frames disorder, and disorder wounds

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Where it should guard. O war, thou son of hell,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Whom angry heavens do make their minister

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Throw in the frozen bosoms of our part

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Hot coals of vengeance! Let no soldier fly.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: He that is truly dedicate to war

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Hath no self-love, nor he that loves himself

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Hath not essentially but by circumstance

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: The name of valour.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Seeing his dead father

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: O, let the vile world end,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: And the premised flames of the last day

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Knit earth and heaven together!

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Now let the general trumpet blow his blast,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Particularities and petty sounds

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: To cease! Wast thou ordaind, dear father,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: To lose thy youth in peace, and to achieve

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: The silver livery of advised age,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: And, in thy reverence and thy chair-days, thus

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: To die in ruffian battle? Even at this sight

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: My heart is turnd to stone: and while tis mine,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: It shall be stony. York not our old men spares;

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: No more will I their babes: tears virginal

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Shall be to me even as the dew to fire,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: And beauty that the tyrant oft reclaims

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Shall to my flaming wrath be oil and flax.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Henceforth I will not have to do with pity:

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Meet I an infant of the house of York,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Into as many gobbets will I cut it

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: As wild Medea young Absyrtus did:

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: In cruelty will I seek out my fame.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Come, thou new ruin of old Cliffords house:

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: As did AEneas old Anchises bear,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: So bear I thee upon my manly shoulders;

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: But then AEneas bare a living load,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Nothing so heavy as these woes of mine.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Exit, bearing off his father

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Enter RICHARD and SOMERSET to fight. SOMERSET is killed

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: So, lie thou there;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For underneath an alehouse paltry sign,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: The Castle in Saint Albans, Somerset

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Hath made the wizard famous in his death.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Sword, hold thy temper; heart, be wrathful still:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Priests pray for enemies, but princes kill.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Exit

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Fight: excursions. Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET, and others

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Away, my lord! you are slow; for shame, away!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Can we outrun the heavens? good Margaret, stay.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What are you made of? youll nor fight nor fly:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Now is it manhood, wisdom and defence,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To give the enemy way, and to secure us

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: By what we can, which can no more but fly.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Alarum afar off

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: If you be taen, we then should see the bottom

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Of all our fortunes: but if we haply scape,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: As well we may, if not through your neglect,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: We shall to London get, where you are loved

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
